title: Watch: ’Rejuvenated’ Bruce back on the job
text:
Watch: Bruce McAvaney addresses his cancer battle during Golden Slipper Day coverage Ben Waterworth, FOX SPORTS March 18, 2017 12:46pm 
A “REVITALISED” and “rejuvenated” Bruce McAvaney hasn’t skipped a beat in his return to TV work less than 24 hours after revealing a two-year long battle with cancer. 
The sporting nation was in shock on Friday after the legendary Australian broadcaster revealed he had been diagnosed with leukaemia over two years ago . 
Despite the health scare, McAvaney affirmed that it wouldn’t deter him from taking part in upcoming sports broadcasts across his most-loved events, including horse racing, AFL, Commonwealth Games and Olympics. 
McAvaney on Saturday was back in the host chair anchoring the Seven Network’s coverage of the Golden Slipper from Rosehill. 
The ever-professional McAvaney kicked off his introduction with a spill on Sydney’s gloomy weather before, as always, turning the attention to the action on the track, highlighting a thrilling race card that included five Group 1s and the mighty mare Winx aiming to keep her undefeated record in tact. media_camera Bruce McAvaney. 
But a minute into the broadcast, co-host Francesca Cumani quickly turned the attention back on McAvanary to discuss Friday’s shock news. 
McAvaney said he was “going well” and thanked the Australian sporting community for the support he’d received over the past 24 hours. 
“About two-and-a half-years ago I found out that I had a form of leukaemia, which is CLL. But I have no symptoms at the moment, I’ve had no treatment for the past two and a half years and if I do happen to have the treatment, the success rate is particularly strong, so I’m very lucky,” McAvaney told Channel 7. 
“It’s a nasty word, leukaemia, there are a lot of people out there fighting it and I feel for them, because in a small way I’ve been in their shoes over the past two and a half years.” 
McAvaney said he was getting “very tired” late last year, which is why he made the decision not to take part in the Australian Open coverage for the first time in over two decades. 
“Probably my immune system is not quite as strong as it once was,” McAvaney said. 
“But I am revitalised, rejuvenated and, as I said, I feel very well.” 
Cumani said she was thrilled to again be working alongside McAvaney. 
“You look incredibly well and your energy is overflowing as always, so it’s great to have you,” Cumani said. 
McAvaney then shifted focus back to the race meet, saying he was “looking forward to today, as we all do” before throwing to a colleague at the mounting yard. 
Bruce was back — and more determined than ever to passionately bring viewers as close to the action as possible.
